greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = r * min(e_1, ..., e_r), where n = p_1^e_1 . .... p_r^e_r is the canonical prime factorization of n, a(1) = 0.
comment: Omega(n) >= a(n) for n >= 1, where Omega(n) = the number of prime factors of n, counting multiplicity.
Positions of records are A000079. - _David A. Corneth_, May 05 2020
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Carlos Rivera, Puzzle #201 The Arithmetic Function A(n), The Prime Puzzles and Problems Connection.
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
mathematica: a[n_] := Module[{pf}, pf = Transpose[FactorInteger[n]]; Length[pf[[1]]]*Min[pf[[2]]]]; Table[a[i] - Boole[i == 1], {i, 100}]
Table[Length[#] Min[#] - Boole[n == 1] &@ FactorInteger[n][[All, -1]], {n, 100}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jul 12 2017 *)
program: print([a(n) for n in range(1, 51)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Jul 13 2017
results.author: _Joseph L. Pe_, Nov 10 2002
